statement.tex: \\ \text{Which of the following shows the}\\ \text{mathematically correct way to start solving?}
\\ \text{If }g(x) = x^{x \cos x},\text{ then which of the following}\\ \text{shows the correct evaluation of }g'(x)?

options.tex: \begin{align} f(x) & = x^{x \cos x} + \, \dfrac{x^2 + 1}{x^2 -1}\\ \implies \log f(x) & = \log(x^{x \cos x}) + \log \left[ \dfrac{x^2 + 1}{x^2 -1}\right]\\ & = x \cos x \cdot \log x + \log \left[ \dfrac{x^2 + 1}{x^2 -1}\right]\\ \end{align} \\ \therefore f'(x) = \frac{d}{dx}(x \cos x \cdot \log x) + \frac{d}{dx}\log \left[ \dfrac{x^2 + 1}{x^2 -1}\right]\\

\begin{align} g(x) &= x^{x \cos x}\\ \implies \log g(x) &= x \cos x \cdot \log x \\ \end{align}\\
\frac{1}{g(x)} g'(x) = \underbrace{x \cos x\frac{d}{dx}\log x + \log x\frac{d}{dx}x \cos x}_{\textbf{Product Rule}} \\
\therefore g'(x) = x^{x \cos x} \left[\, \cos x \cdot (1 + \log x) - x \sin x \cdot \log x \right]
